Fujitsu develops system to prevent accidents caused by misplaced objects on roads, tests it in company vehicles | Central Japan Economic News, economic information from Aichi, Gifu, Mie, and Shizuoka

FUJI (headquarters: Kizugawa-shi), which handles the manufacturing and sales of robots and work machines, has started developing a system to prevent "forgetting" such as leaving children in the car, etc.
A car with a motion sensor installed inside it will send notifications to your phone or chat when it detects movement.
We are currently conducting a field test using our own vehicles.
While tragic accidents happen, we must protect our children.

Currently, two vehicles are being used to test the effectiveness of the service for Teracoya THANK, an after-school English conversation class for children operated by the company within the city of Kizugawa.
We installed three human-presence sensors, which detect movement by sensing the temperature difference between a person and their surroundings, in the ceiling of the car.
If the engine is turned off and the door is closed, and after a certain period of time, it detects movement of a person, it will automatically send a notification.
By linking engine and door status and information, we can prevent false alarms as much as possible.
The warning messages are broadcast through the cloud.
You can also use it to display your number on your computer or smartphone chat.
You can register multiple addresses and it will help you avoid missing deliveries.
The trial will continue until the end of February.

"During the experiment, we were able to see the surrounding issues that are not related to the system," said Katsuya Kawakami, the director of the second section of the Innovation Promotion Department.
For example, we could build an environment that allows drivers to focus on driving, and tackle a variety of issues related to school buses.
"Let's spread the solution," he said, with determination.
The development of a prevention system for abandoned buses was triggered by a series of incidents involving abandoned buses across the country.
A suggestion was made by an employee with children that there must be something we can do to ensure the safety of our children.
We decided to develop the technology to apply the know-how we have cultivated in FA (factory automation) related businesses, such as IoT (Internet of Things) and sensors, to information management.
Fujifilm's disposal prevention system is easy to use.
The sensor can be installed just by sticking it to the ceiling.
The ease of following the shuttle buses will lower the hurdle to introduction and aim for widespread use.
Going forward, we will consider productization while relying on cooperation with daycare centers and kindergartens.

[Opinion] Oita City is making and distributing "Ending Notes" to the citizens who hope for the city.

Last year, he published a comprehensive "bereavement handbook" that includes necessary procedures and writing styles for wills, an inheritance list, and a family tree, and many people who wanted to prepare for themselves came to receive a copy.
In the prefecture, there are seminars on how to write an ending note and how to prepare for death in various locations, and "end-of-life" has become a common topic among the citizens.
The population of Oita City is 35,000.

Chapter 5 starts with a review of your history, and then goes on to record your current health status and assets, your wishes for future care, end-of-life medical care, funeral arrangements and burial or cremation.
There is also a section for things you want to do in the rest of your life and a place to leave messages for loved ones.
I say 35 but it doesn’t have to be filled to the brim.
What would you want to leave behind for your family and the people around you?
The hard part is making sure you have a clear goal.
You can buy a variety of notebooks in bookstores and other places, and start writing anywhere you can.
The term "retirement" was created in 1909, when the concept of retirement was introduced.
Two years later, in 2011, the Great East Japan Earthquake occurred.
It is said that more and more people are preparing for their own death and end of life, as they are confronted with the reality that "death comes suddenly".
It's been more than 10 years since then.
The new coronavirus pandemic, which has spread around the world, is still not under control.
Prices have soared in Russia due to the Ukraine invasion and other factors, and electricity prices this winter have skyrocketed to unbelievable levels.
On the other hand, wages have not kept up with the current inflation, and many people are worried about the future.
On the other hand, once upon a time, there were burial fees and nursing fees that could be shared with relatives, but nowadays, it is not uncommon for young people to be left alone.
Another dilemma is that while life expectancy has increased significantly in recent years, the risk of cognitive impairment and need for care increases as we age.
We must also remember that the background of such social unrest is the fact that the end of life is only temporary.
Either way, I think most people would agree that they don't want to put too much pressure on Portner or their kids.
"Dying with dignity" is a popular keyword on Ending Note, but it can't be left to individuals alone.
I don't want to write down my hopes and wishes in secret, but I want to talk to my family about it and prepare for that time in a calm way.

NPO Corporation "Resonating Anthology / Editorial Office" self-published book "Dear Prime Minister, Mr. Abe, "The Levee of Life" from Tou Shuken"
"Dear Prime Minister, from Toshimikubo, the bastion of life" I self-published my 10th book with this title.
All the newspapers in the country have taken it up, and we have received many letters from readers expressing their feelings.

The purpose of publishing this book is to share with everyone the content that directly heard from the suicidal planners about the "social and structural" environment that is the cause of suicide in Japan, and to create a "society where people want to live" by fulfilling the wish to solve this problem.

We have been supporting activities to prevent suicide for 18 years and 10 months at the Tsukinofu in Fukui Prefecture, which is known as a suicide spot, by patrolling the cliffs, discovering and protecting those who are planning to commit suicide, and helping them to restart their lives.

An exhibition that pays tribute to the pioneers who laid the foundation for plant research in Mount Omine, a treasure trove of high-altitude plants, is being held at the City Cultural Asset Center in Omiya, Saitama, until the 12th.
The article collects 124 valuable samples and documents collected by predecessors, and introduces the footprints of predecessors in the study of plants on Mount Emei.

The study of plants on Mount Omine began with the arrival of Russian botanist Carl Johann Maximowicz (1827-91) at the end of the Edo period, and the collection of plants under the guidance of Maximowicz by Sugawara Nagayoshi (1842-1925), who was born in Puru-cho.
The Maximus was a foreigner who was not allowed to freely walk around the country, so he asked Sugawara to collect it, and he continued research for three years from bases in Yokohama and Nagasaki.

After returning from the maximum altitude, Sukawa continued to support research and announced the unique species of the Mount Fuji area, such as the "Himekosazura", "Nanboutouuchisou", and "Miyamayamabukishouma".

After that, the modern plant taxonomist Miyoshi Fukuzo (1862-1957) published "Nambutranon" "Kobanotsumeke" "Nambiyinazana" in 1903 (Meiji 36), and "Katouhakohebe" which he discovered and named himself on Mount Oyama in 1905 (Meiji 38).
From the exhibits, it is clear that many researchers have discovered valuable high-altitude plants.

We also introduce the flowering plants of Mt. Oyama, which were collected by the principal of Hachimangu Elementary School, Sugimura Masanori (1874-1948), who was researching plants during the survey for the preservation of natural monuments in 1927 (Showa 2), and by Tamura Shichiro (1914-88), who was an artisan at the

"There are many studies and connections between the names of the plants on Mt. Oyama, one by one," says Yoshida Toshihide, a researcher at the same center. "We can connect researchers from all over the country through these connections."

The exhibition is divided into four chapters. The first chapter is about the faith and history of Mt. Ashio, the second chapter is about the German geologist Hainrich Eduard Naumann (1854-1927) who built the foundation of Japanese geology, and the third chapter is about the features of Mt. Ashio from the perspective of geology.
